title: Is this REALLY the worst hotel in Manchester? We check in to find out
text:
What's On Is this REALLY the worst hotel in Manchester? We check in to find out Guests on TripAdvisor rated this Manchester Hotel the worst in the city - but is it really as bad as the reviews say? This is the Manchester hotel that guests on TripAdvisor have said is like: “something out of a horror movie” while another said they’d “rather sleep on the street” than spend another night there. 
The Merchants Hotel in the Northern Quarter has racked up 266 ‘terrible’ ratings out of the 389 it has been awarded on the review website, giving it the worst rating in Manchester. 
But is it really as bad as all those guests would have us believe? Read More According to TripAdvisor reviewers these are the five worst hotels in Greater Manchester 
We checked in on a Friday night to find out. 
We paid £42 for a single room at the hotel - which came with a shower and sink but not a toilet - instead there was a shared toilet at the end of the corridor. And you have to pay an extra £2 for a towel. View gallery 
Clearly at this sort of price, no one would expect the Ritz, but I was still shocked to find how basic the state of the room was, with very dated decor, old patterned carpets and one of the most disgusting chairs I think I have ever layed eyes on, encrusted with various layers of grime, it even crunched to the touch, and the back of the chair was falling off. 
There were stains and cracks in the walls around the bed, with what looked like previous water damage. 
Indeed, there were more of these stains and cracks on the main stairwell walls - although there was a painter and decorator hard at work when I visited, and bosses have confirmed they have started a programme of improvements to the hotel which will continue throughout 2017. 
The corridor leading to my room was also clean and well painted, with what looked like a newer carpet, and the shared toilet was, thankfully, nice and clean too. 
In terms of location, it does have something to boast about - as central as you like just off Piccadilly Gardens, with fantastic access to all city centre attractions, with buses, trams and Piccadilly Train Station all a short stroll away. Read More A pop up cinema is coming to a listed Manchester mill 
But the entrance to the hotel on Back Piccadilly comes with it’s own problems - the road is filled with huge wheelie bins, litter spilling on to the street, and an unpleasant stench from the unwelcome, ahem, deposits from the city’s revellers along the gutters. 
I dread to think what first time visitors to Manchester must think when they walk out and see this grimmer than grim street view. Welcome to Manchester! The view outside the main entrance of the Merchants Hotel on Back Piccadilly in Manchester. (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Sure, this is not the fault of the hotel, but its own entrance does little to give a good impression for a guest arriving. 
There is graffiti on the door, and one of the information boxes contains a dirty looking sheet of paper detailing room prices. 
Without an apparent hint of irony, the crumpled up sheet says: "We invite you to experience the luxury of being treated like Royalty". The entrance to the Merchants Hotel on Back Piccadilly in Manchester - the crumpled sheet invites you "to enjoy the luxury of being treated like royalty" (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Buzzing myself in, I walk up a flight of stairs to the main reception, where there is at least the sight of a very friendly receptionist who gives me a warm welcome. 
But while the hotel is billed as a bed and breakfast, I’m informed it will actually cost me £3 for breakfast in the morning - which comes served in a bag containing a box of cereal, a bottle of milk, carton of fruit juice and biscuit that you can tip out and serve yourself in the bowl in your bedroom. 
Heading up to the room to sleep, I’m pleased to see that at least the bed linen looks clean and fresh, and the mattress is comfortable enough as I nestle down to rest. Single bedroom at The Merchants Hotel on Back Piccadilly in Manchester. (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
As the mother of a young child, I was looking forward to a rare uninterrupted night’s sleep - but alas even that was not to be. 
For at 5am I’m awoken by the sound of bins being emptied on Back Piccadilly - and the noise, clear as a bell through the single pane window, just keeps on and on, with a nagging succession of delivery vans, wheeling trollies and breaking bottles, and loud conversations until at 7am I give up trying to rest and just get up out of bed. 
I’m starting to understand why one Trip Advisor reviewer said you might as well: “sleep on the street instead”. 
When I mention the noise to the receptionist as I’m leaving, he apologises and says it’s a constant problem they have which they have raised with the council, and that many other guests have raised a similar complaint, with the noise affecting the rooms on the Back Piccadilly side of the hotel, although I’m told that the en suite rooms are available on the other side of the hotel which are not affected by the noise. 
We contacted the hotel with the full details of our experience, and manager Shahid Naseeb said the specific issues raised about the bedroom have been flagged and “will receive due attention immediately”. The reception at the Merchants Hotel on Back Piccadilly in Manchester. (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
He said: “We are a small family run business in a very competitive market place dominated by multi-national brands. 
“As a running business it is difficult to carry out significant upgrades due to commitments to our guests who book with us many weeks in advance. 
“We have however recognised that to stay competitive and to provide our guests with a comfortable experience we need to improve the amenities on offer. 
“We have an extensive redecoration and improvement plan for 2017. As the building is leased we are limited in the scope of this work due to contractual obligations to not alter the internal footprint of the building. We are however committed to making any improvements that we can.” 
Mr Naseeb confirmed that the issues with noise on Back Piccadilly have been reported to Environmental Health. 
He said: “In regards to the noise outside this is outside of our control. The development on the old Nobles Arcade has left the area directly in front of our door as a hotbed of noise and at times unruly behaviour. I have mentioned this to Morrisons, Travelodge and Zizzi who leave their bins on the roadside, but they refuse to move them or arrange collection of these during normal social hours. I have also reported this to environmental health for noise and cleanliness but have not received any satisfactory response.” The Merchants Hotel on Back Piccadilly in Manchester. (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
He added that the state of Back Piccadilly is now something that all stakeholders in the area need to address. 
In regards to all those one star TripAdvisor reviews, Mr Naseeb said: “These aren’t always objective nor verified. I prefer to focus on our reviews from our online travel agent partners (Expedia and booking.com) where reviews are objective and verified. We have a 60% rating on these sites and are continually looking to improve this.” 
The hotel has 23 bedrooms, ranging from basic single rooms with shared toilet and shower facilities starting from £35 a night up to en suite double bedrooms that start at £55. Read More
